Article Title: Passport application rules are changing for these citizens
Article Text:
What‚Äôs new for applicants

The government has updated the passport application process with stricter rules. As part of these changes, children born on or after October 1, 2023 must provide a birth certificate as the sole proof of their date of birth. This change follows the implementation of the Registration of Births and Deaths (Amendment) Act, 2023 and is aimed to make the verification process simpler and more consistent. However, for those born before October 1, 2023, the rules remain the same, allowing applicants to continue using alternative documents like school leaving certificates, PAN cards, driving licenses, or extracts from service records as proof of birth.Under the new regulations, only birth certificates issued by municipal corporations, the registrar of births and deaths, or any authorized body under the Registration of Births and Deaths Act , 1969, will be accepted. The new rule will take effect once it is published in the official Gazette.Also read: Zepto CEO Aadit Palicha corrects Zomato CEO Deepinder Goyal in an open LinkedIn post: ‚ÄòWith due respect, this statement is‚Ä¶‚Äô The government has also made several changes to the passport's format and security features. One significant update is the removal of the applicant's residential address from the last page of the passport. Instead, this information will now be embedded in a barcode that immigration officers can scan when needed, reducing the risk of personal details being misused.In addition to this, the government has introduced a new color-coded system for passports. White passports will be issued to government officials, red passports will be designated for diplomats, and blue passports will continue to be the standard for ordinary citizens. The policy regarding the inclusion of parents' names on passports has also been revised. In a move that benefits individuals from separated or single-parent families, the last page of the passport will no longer display parental details, ensuring that applicants are not required to disclose unnecessary personal information.To meet the increasing demand for passport services, the government has announced plans to expand the number of Post Office Passport Seva Kendras (POPSKs) from 442 to 600 over the next five years, making passport services more accessible across the country.
Article Summary: The government has updated the passport application process with stricter rules. Children born on or after October 1, 2023 must provide a birth certificate as the sole proof of their date of birth. The government has also made several changes to the passport's format and security features. The last page of the passport will no longer display parental details.

Article Title: Infosys layoffs: Karnataka government gives clean chit to the company; says there was no ... relationship
Article Text: The Karnataka Labour Department has officially given Infosys a clean chit regarding the recent layoffs of trainees at its Mysuru campus. Following an inquiry into allegations of labour law violations , the department concluded that the company had not breached any legal requirements, as the affected individuals were classified as trainees rather than employees.‚ÄúWe have not found any violation of labour laws in our inspection at Infosys‚Ä¶There was no employee and employer relationship between them in the first place. They were not even given appointment letters for them to be called employees. They were trainees for three months who were paid stipends and were part of the apprenticeship program,‚Äù confirmed a government official.The investigation was prompted by complaints from the Nascent Information Technology Employees Senate ( NITES ) and affected trainees, who claimed the layoffs were unethical and violated labour laws. Infosys had terminated approximately 350-400 trainees on February 7, citing their inability to clear internal assessments after three attempts. The company emphasised that performance evaluations are a standard part of its globally recognised training program.In its interim report, the Karnataka Labour Department clarified that the state government cannot intervene in the selection or evaluation processes of private companies. The department also noted that Infosys had adhered to its policies by providing outplacement services, severance pay , and counselling to the trainees who were let go.Labour Minister Santhosh Lad ordered an inspection of Infosys campuses in Mysuru and Bengaluru, conducted by a team led by G Manjunath. The review of hiring documents revealed that while more than 600 students from the 2022 batch moved forward, 329 failed a required test. Government officials also raised concerns about Infosys's terminology.Despite the clean chit, NITES has expressed dissatisfaction with the findings and warned of potential protests. The union continues to advocate for stronger protections for trainees and employees in the IT sector, calling for greater transparency and fairness in hiring and evaluation practices.

The entities have also been barred from accessing the securities market.The order also uncovered that fees collected from participants were routed through entities such as King Traders (proprietor: Sagar Dhanjibhai), Gemini Enterprise (proprietor: Suresh Parmashivam), and United Enterprises (proprietor: Jigar Rameshbhai Dawada). The acts of the Noticee no.1 makes it evident that it was providing investment advice/ research analyst services to students/investors/participants for a consideration in the pretext of imparting education.‚Äù

Article Title: Microsoft unveils Dragon Copilot, AI Voice Assistant for healthcare

Extensions that have not been upgraded to Manifest V3 are being disabled or removed from the Chrome Web Store.The impact of this transition extends beyond Chrome, affecting other Chromium-based browsers like Microsoft Edge and Brave. While Brave has confirmed it will offer limited support for ad blockers after the transition, Firefox has stated it will continue to support Manifest V2 extensions, providing a potential alternative for users who rely on ad-blocking tools.As Google continues to roll out Manifest V3, users and developers are voicing their concerns about the implications for online privacy and user control. The debate over the balance between security and functionality in browser extensions is likely to continue as the transition progresses.
Article Summary: Google has begun disabling several popular Chrome extensions, including the widely-used ad blocker uBlock Origin. This is part of its transition to the new Manifest V3 specification. With this move, the company expects to cut overall inventory by over $300 million by March 2026.However, Microchip anticipates incurring between $30 million and $40 million in costs related to the layoffs, including severance and restructuring expenses, the report added. The company also said the job cuts will be revealed to employees this month and fully implemented by the end of the June quarter.All this is expected to cut the company‚Äôs ongoing operating expenses by nearly $90 million to $100 million per year, the report claims. In addition to the nearly $90 million in annual cash savings from the Arizona fab closure disclosed in December, further layoffs at various facilities are projected to reduce employment-related costs at Microchip's factories by an additional $25 million.Microchip‚Äôs automotive customers have faced challenges clearing their chip inventories after stockpiling supplies during pandemic-related disruptions. As a result, the chip company's shares dropped by over 36% in 2024.Microchip has also revealed plans to sell its integrated circuit die to a Chinese partner. The partner will test, assemble, and market the products under a Chinese brand. Similarly, rival chipmakers like Allegro Microsystems have initiated efforts to localize their supply chains in China.Meanwhile, rising US-China tensions are also posing risks for chipmakers that rely on revenue from China, a key market for many auto industry suppliers.
Article Summary: Microchip Technology has announced it will cut around 2,000 jobs, or about 9% of its workforce, in response to slowing demand. The headcount reductions will primarily affect its factories in Oregon and Colorado in the US. Layoffs will also occur at the Arizona-based company‚Äôs backend facility in the Philippines.

European telecommunications executives gathered at Europe's biggest trade show -- Mobile World Congress (MWC) in Barcelona -- seem quite upset with the excessive regulation in the region. In the 5G era, we‚Äôre trailing.‚Äù Many executives see mergers as the solution, but regulators across Europe have repeatedly thwarted or altered deals that would shrink the number of operators per market from four to three, prioritizing affordable consumer prices.Hottges argued, ‚ÄúWe should just copy what the Americans are doing,‚Äù said H√∂ttges, whose Deutsche Telekom gets most of its revenue and profit from a stake in US operator T-Mobile US Inc. ‚ÄúChina has three operators, even India went to three operators and they are prospering.‚ÄùThe discussion capped a day of frustration aired by leaders from firms like Telefonica, Emirates Telecommunications Group, Telenor ASA, and Bharti Airtel Ltd, all of whom lamented the lack of financial payoff for their costly network investments.
